person_101.name: Ambrosio
person_101.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_108.name: Onuphrio
person_108.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

person_122.name: The Unknown
person_122.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_964.name: Johann Weikhardvon Valvasor
person_964.description: FRS. A natural historian and polymath from Carniola, present-day Slovenia.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_1119.name: SigmundZois
person_1119.description: Sigmund Zois Freiherr von Edelstein, usually referred as Sigmund Zois, was a Carniolan nobleman, natural scientist and patron of the arts. He is considered one of the most influential figures of the Enlightenment Era in the Slovene Lands of Habsburg Austria.

person_421.name: SigmundZois
person_421.description: Wealthy mining magnate in what is now Slovenia. A influential intellectual  and keen amateur mineralogist.

person_471.name: WilliamHarvey
person_471.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

person_965.name: Carl Franz Anton Rittervon Schreibers
person_965.description: an Austrian naturalist who was the first to perform a comprehensive anatomical study of the olm.

person_810.name: Alexander III
person_810.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

person_271.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
person_271.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

person_231.name: JosephBlack
person_231.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_1112.name: Isaac
person_1112.description: Second son of Abraham and Sarah in the Bible

person_1113.name: Jacob
person_1113.description: Biblical Prophet, son of Isaac and Rebecca

person_973.name: Saint Paul
person_973.description: A Christian apostle who spread the teachings of Jesus in the first-century world. For his contributions towards the New Testament, he is generally regarded as one of the most important figures of the Apostolic Age.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_151.name: Edward CharlesHoward
person_151.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

person_275.name: Prometheus
person_275.description: In Greek mythology, defied the Olympian gods by stealing fire and giving it to humans.

person_508.name: Lucretius
person_508.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

person_801.name: Herodotus
person_801.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_417.name: Archimedes
person_417.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

person_602.name: Plutarch
person_602.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_1114.name: AdamSmith
person_1114.description: A Scottish economist and philosopher who was a pioneer in the thinking of political economy and key figure during the Scottish Enlightenment.

person_135.name: JosiahWedgwood
person_135.description: Renowned British potter whose factory was at Etruria near Stoke-on-Trent. A strong supporter of the abolition of the slave trade and of slavery, he was closely connected with other industrialists in the Midlands. FRSL.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_991.name: Athenaeus
person_991.description: Athenaeus of Naucratis was a Greek rhetorician and grammarian, who lived sometime around the end of the 2nd and beginning of the 3rd century AD.

person_406.name: Alfred
person_406.description: King of the West Saxons from 871 to 886, and King of the Anglo-Saxons from 886 until his death in 899.

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_089.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
person_089.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_907.name: Nice
place_907.description: Capital of the Alpes-Maritimes department on the French Riviera.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_569.name: Sicily
place_569.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

place_201.name: Austria
place_201.description: Austria, formally the Republic of Austria, is a landlocked country in Central Europe, lying in the Eastern Alps.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_328.name: Tyrol
place_328.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

place_192.name: Illyrian Alps
place_192.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

place_193.name: Noric Alps
place_193.description: The Noric Alps is a collective term for a group of mountain ranges in the Eastern Alps.

place_194.name: Julian Alps
place_194.description: The Julian Alps are a mountain range in the Southern Limestone Alps, Slovenia. Mount Triglav is the highest point.

place_196.name: Styria
place_196.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

place_197.name: Salzburg
place_197.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

place_200.name: Dead Sea
place_200.description: The Dead Sea is a salt lake in the Jordan Rift Valley.

place_1404.name: Austrian States
place_1404.description: Austria is a federal republic consisting of nine federal states. The European Commission calls them provinces.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_687.name: Linz
place_687.description: Linz is a city in Upper Austria, straddling the Danube River midway between Salzburg and Vienna.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_182.name: Traun
place_182.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

place_257.name: Gmunden
place_257.description: Gmunden is a town in Upper Austria, frequented as a health and summer resort.

place_972.name: Traunsee
place_972.description: A lake in the Salzkammergut, Upper Austria, Austria.

place_1263.name: Schaffhausen
place_1263.description: historically known in English as Shaffhouse, is a municipality in northern Switzerland, located right next to the shore of the High Rhine

place_259.name: Hallstätter See
place_259.description: Hallstatter is a lake in Austria named after the small town on its shore.

place_229.name: Bad Aussee
place_229.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

place_424.name: Lake Toplitz
place_424.description: A lake in a dense forest high in the Austrian Alps.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_426.name: Adige
place_426.description: The second-longest river in Italy, which rises in the province of South Tyrol, near the Italian border with Austria and Switzerland.

place_582.name: Black Sea
place_582.description: The Black Sea is a marginal Mediterranean sea lying between Europe and Asia, east of the Balkans, south of the East European Plain, west of the Caucasus, and north of Anatolia.

place_729.name: Adriatic Sea
place_729.description: The Adriatic Sea lies between the Italian Peninsula and the Balkan Peninsula. It is the northernmost section of the Mediterranean Sea.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_343.name: Triglav
place_343.description: Also known as Terglou. Triglav is the highest mountain in Slovenia, located in the Julian Alps.

place_314.name: Manhart
place_314.description: Mangart is a mountain in the Julian Alps on the border between Austria and Slovenia.

place_558.name: Lake Bohinj
place_558.description: Lake Bohinj is the largest permanent lake in Slovenia.

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_428.name: Postojna
place_428.description: A town in the traditional region of Inner Carniola, 35 km from Trieste, in south-western Slovenia.

place_423.name: Lake Cerknica
place_423.description: An intermittent lake in the southern part of the Cerknica Polje, a region in south-western Slovenia.

place_181.name: Carniola
place_181.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

place_593.name: Stična
place_593.description: Also known as Sittich. Stična is a village in Slovenia, lying just north of Ivančna Gorica and is best known for its Cistercian abbey.

place_1248.name: Postojna
place_1248.description: a town in the traditional region of Inner Carniola, in southwestern Slovenia

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_1426.name: Arctic
place_1426.description: The Arctic is the polar region of Earth that surrounds the North Pole, lying within the Arctic Circle.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_1412.name: Aare
place_1412.description: The Aare or Aaris the main tributary of the High Rhine (its discharge even exceeds that of the latter at their confluence)and the longest river that both rises and ends entirely within Switzerland

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_685.name: New Holland
place_685.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

place_1405.name: river Belus
place_1405.description: Also known as Na'mein River, river in Palestine

place_154.name: St. Peter's
place_154.description: St Peter's is a church built in the Renaissance style located in the Vatican City, west of the River Tiber.

place_1406.name: Dresden
place_1406.description: the capital city of the German state of Saxony

place_1407.name: Sevres
place_1407.description: a French commune in the southwestern suburbs of Paris

place_1145.name: Pula
place_1145.description: A seafront city on the tip of Croatia’s Istrian Peninsula.

place_1144.name: Istria
place_1144.description: The largest peninsula within the Adriatic Sea

place_622.name: Verona
place_622.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

place_615.name: Tiber River
place_615.description: The Tiber River is the third longest river in Italy. Rome is located on its banks.

place_926.name: Sabina
place_926.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

place_211.name: British Museum
place_211.description: The British Museum is a public museum dedicated to human history, art, and culture located in the Bloomsbury area of London.

place_1427.name: Parthenon
place_1427.description: The Parthenon is a former temple on the Athenian Acropolis, Greece, that was dedicated to the goddess Athena. Its decorative sculptures are considered some of the high points of classical Greek art, and the Parthenon is considered an enduring symbol of Ancient Greece, democracy, and Western civilization.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_1408.name: Mausoleum of Theodoric
place_1408.description: An ancient monument just outside Ravenna, Italy

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_1409.name: Corsica
place_1409.description: an island in the Mediterranean Sea

place_770.name: Pisa
place_770.description: Pisa is a city in Italy's Tuscany region best known for its iconic Leaning Tower.

place_293.name: Lizard
place_293.description: A village on the Lizard peninsula in Cornwall, England.

place_509.name: Lizard Point
place_509.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

place_1136.name: New South Wales
place_1136.description: Today, a state on the east coast of Australia; named in 1770 by Lieutenant James Cook, and founded as a British penal colony in 1788, it originally comprised more than half of the Australian mainland with its western boundary set at 129th meridian east in 1825.

otherwork_284.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_284.author: Johann Weikhard von Valvasor
